page.title: 03Landscape Around Maltby
page.content: The Maltby district is part of a gently sloping dip-slope of Magnesian limestone. Near the western margins this reaches 120 metres OD,declining to below 70 metres in the east. The dip slope is cut into by the steep sided valley of Maltby Dyke, where the limestone is exposed in impressive crags. Much of the dip slope is good arable farmland,but the steeper valley sides form areas of rough grass,scrub and woodland of higher landscape and amenity value. East of the town is a poorly drained area of common land,now designated a SSSI.In the east Sandbeck Park,the estate of Lord Scarbrough,has game coverts and plantations adding to the scenery.Northeast the colliery spoil heap and stone quarries mar the landscape.Thus man has both improved and scarred the landscape.
